news_summary: Astronomers have made an exciting discovery by observing a neutron star unexpectedly reawaken, shedding new light on stellar behavior.
news_summary_fr: Des astronomes ont fait une découverte passionnante en observant le réveil inattendu d'une étoile à neutrons, jetant ainsi un nouvel éclairage sur le comportement stellaire.
news_summary_es: Los astrónomos han realizado un emocionante descubrimiento al observar cómo una estrella de neutrones se reaviva inesperadamente, arrojando nueva luz sobre el comportamiento estelar.

articles.title: Astronomers watched a sleeping neutron star roar back to life
articles.summary: Astronomers tracked a decade of dramatic changes in P13, a neutron star undergoing supercritical accretion. Its X-ray luminosity rose and fell by factors of hundreds while its rotation rate accelerated. These synchronized shifts suggest the accretion structure itself evolved over time. The findings offer fresh clues to how ultraluminous X-ray sources reach such extreme power.
articles.content:
When gas falls onto a compact object, such as a neutron star or black hole, due to its strong gravity (a process called accretion), it emits electromagnetic waves. High-sensitivity observations have discovered objects with extremely high X-ray luminosities. One possible explanation for the ultraluminosity is that an extraordinary amount of gas falls onto a compact object through a process called supercritical accretion. However, the mechanism of supercritical accretion remains unclear.

The research team focused on NGC 7793 P13 (hereafter, P13), which is a neutron star in supercritical accretion, located in the galaxy NGC 7793 (about 10 million light-years from the Earth). As gas falls onto a neutron star, it forms a column structure (called an accretion column) on magnetic poles, from which intense X-ray is thought to be emitted. Then, coherent X-ray pulsation accompanied by the rotation of a neutron star can be detected. According to previous studies, P13 rotates with a period of 0.4 s with a constant acceleration rate. Moreover, the luminosity changed by more than two orders of magnitude in about 10 years. Both rotation velocity and luminosity are effective parameters to estimate the amount of gas accreted. However, the relation between them was not found for P13.

The research team investigated the long-term evolution of the X-ray luminosity and rotation period of P13 from 2011 to 2024, using the archival data of XMM-Newton, Chandra, NuSTAR, and NICER. It was found that P13 was in a faint phase in 2021 and started to be bright again in 2022. By 2024, it reached a high luminosity, more than two orders of magnitude higher than in 2021. Moreover, in the rebrightening phase in 2022, the acceleration rate of the rotation velocity was increased by a factor of 2, and it was maintained until 2024. This result suggests a relationship between X-ray luminosity and rotation velocity, and that the accretion system changed during the faint phase. The research team then focused on the pulsation and performed detailed analyses. It was suggested that the height of the accretion column was changed with the 10-year flux modulation. Those results are expected to be clues to reveal the mechanism of supercritical accretion.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery about neutron stars and supercritical accretion, providing new insights into ultraluminous X-ray sources. This breakthrough advances understanding of extreme cosmic phenomena, which has broad significance for astrophysics and space science.
articles.personality_title: Astronomers observe a neutron star’s powerful comeback after years of quiet
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Neutron stars are incredibly dense objects left behind after a star explodes. Some of them pull in gas from their surroundings, a process called accretion, which can make them shine brightly in X-rays. Scientists study these bright X-rays to learn how neutron stars grow and change.

**What happened** – Researchers watched a neutron star named P13 in a galaxy 10 million light-years away. From 2011 to 2024, they tracked its X-ray brightness and how fast it spins. They saw that after getting very faint in 2021, P13 suddenly became much brighter by 2024. At the same time, it spun faster, with its spin speed increasing twice as fast as before.

**Impact** – This is the first time scientists have seen the brightness and spin speed change together like this over many years. It shows that the way gas falls onto the neutron star changed over time. These findings help explain how some neutron stars become extremely bright in X-rays, a mystery that has puzzled astronomers.

**What's next step** – Scientists plan to keep watching P13 and similar stars to understand more about how the gas forms columns near the star’s magnetic poles and how this affects their brightness and spin. This could reveal the full process behind supercritical accretion, where neutron stars pull in gas at huge rates.

**One-sentence takeaway** – By tracking P13’s changing brightness and spin over a decade, astronomers uncovered new clues about how neutron stars grow by pulling in gas at extreme levels.
articles.personality_title_fr: Les astronomes observent le puissant retour d’une étoile à neutrons après des années de silence
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Les étoiles à neutrons sont des objets très denses laissés après l’explosion d’une étoile. Certaines attirent du gaz autour d’elles, un processus appelé accrétion, ce qui peut les faire briller fortement en rayons X. Les scientifiques étudient ces rayons X pour comprendre comment ces étoiles évoluent.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Des chercheurs ont observé une étoile à neutrons nommée P13 dans une galaxie située à 10 millions d’années-lumière. Entre 2011 et 2024, ils ont suivi sa luminosité en rayons X et sa vitesse de rotation. Après une période de faible luminosité en 2021, P13 est redevenue beaucoup plus brillante en 2024. En même temps, sa vitesse de rotation a doublé.

**Impact** – C’est la première fois que l’on observe une telle variation simultanée de la luminosité et de la vitesse de rotation sur plusieurs années. Cela montre que la manière dont le gaz tombe sur l’étoile a changé avec le temps. Ces résultats aident à comprendre comment certaines étoiles à neutrons deviennent extrêmement brillantes en rayons X, un mystère pour les astronomes.

**Prochaine étape** – Les scientifiques vont continuer à observer P13 et d’autres étoiles similaires pour mieux comprendre comment le gaz forme des colonnes près des pôles magnétiques et comment cela influence la luminosité et la rotation. Cela pourrait révéler le mécanisme complet de l’accrétion supercritique, où les étoiles attirent beaucoup de gaz.

**Résumé en une phrase** – En suivant la luminosité et la rotation de P13 pendant dix ans, les astronomes ont découvert de nouveaux indices sur la croissance des étoiles à neutrons par accrétion extrême.
articles.personality_title_es: Los astrónomos observan el poderoso regreso de una estrella de neutrones tras años de silencio
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Las estrellas de neutrones son objetos muy densos que quedan después de que una estrella explota. Algunas atraen gas de su entorno, un proceso llamado acreción, que puede hacer que brillen mucho en rayos X. Los científicos estudian estos rayos X para entender cómo crecen y cambian estas estrellas.

**Qué pasó** – Un equipo de investigadores observó una estrella de neutrones llamada P13 en una galaxia a 10 millones de años luz. Entre 2011 y 2024, midieron su brillo en rayos X y su velocidad de giro. Después de estar muy tenue en 2021, P13 volvió a brillar mucho en 2024. Al mismo tiempo, su velocidad de giro se aceleró al doble.

**Impacto** – Es la primera vez que se ve un cambio simultáneo en brillo y velocidad de giro durante varios años. Esto muestra que la forma en que el gas cae sobre la estrella cambió con el tiempo. Estos resultados ayudan a explicar cómo algunas estrellas de neutrones alcanzan niveles muy altos de brillo en rayos X, algo que antes no se entendía.

**Próximo paso** – Los científicos seguirán observando a P13 y otras estrellas similares para entender mejor cómo el gas forma columnas cerca de los polos magnéticos y cómo eso afecta el brillo y la rotación. Esto podría explicar completamente el proceso de acreción supercrítica, cuando las estrellas atraen gas a gran velocidad.

**Resumen en una frase** – Al seguir el brillo y la rotación de P13 por una década, los astrónomos obtuvieron nuevas pistas sobre cómo las estrellas de neutrones crecen al atraer gas de forma extrema.
